messageBody:
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> albsavoia wrote:
>
>> Feedback?
>
> Here is how I see practice rolling out:
>
> 1. Practitioners generate a great idea.
> 2. Practitioners test the idea: some like it, some don't.
> 3. If enough like it, some start teaching it.
> 4. If enough teach it, some /schools/ start teaching it.
> 5. If enough schools teach it, it becomes part of the standard curriculum.
> 6. If it becomes part of the standard curriculum, generations of
> practitioners treat it as "the way we do things".
>
> I think we're waiting for step 5. I suspect that by the time we reach
> step 6, there will be people at step 2 saying that TDD is "so 1999."

I teach at a small, liberal-arts college (http://cs.calvin.edu), and
this is my TDD-in-the-classroom testimony...

I got test-infected back in 2002. It took me a couple semesters after
that, but I finally realized that CS 1 is actually *easier* with JUnit.
I started using it in the CS 1 labs and projects, and students seemed
to respond well. They actually responded much better to JUnit tests
than to command-line drivers. CL drivers never work the way students
would like, mostly because parsing is so tricky.

A colleague started using unit tests in CS 2 as well. Unfortunately, CS
2 for us is in C++, and my colleague was more happy with the standard
C++ "assert" than any C++ unit-testing library.

In either case, I have to stress that we teach *unit testing* in CS 1
and CS 2. There is no way these students would be able to handle
refactoring.

I'm currently on sabbatical, and my project is to work on teaching
materials (lab manual and maybe even a textbook) for a Programming
Languages course (taken 2nd semester, sophomore year). My approach to
this course is for students to build interpreters using incremental
development and *true* TDD. What's really cool about this is that most
(if not all) refactorings are just transformations based on PL theory,
so I can justify it on PL grounds, not just good-practice grounds.

The problem now is a missing step in Joe's "algorithm". I'd add a step:

3.5. If enough teach it, teaching materials get produced.

While this step is implicit in steps 4 and 5, I think *right now* it's
the sticking point in the process, and so I'm going to make the step
explicit.

To my knowledge, no Java or C++ introductory textbooks describe or use
JUnit. There are some excellent books on JUnit and TDD, but they're
written for reasonably experienced programmers. We need materials for
the beginning programmer. My CS 1 lab manual (which uses JUnit
everywhere, all the time) is currently just for private use; I am
planning to get it published somehow, somewhere. I hope to do the same
to my PL materials.
